doc.repnme: Reforme sectorielle de l'eau et de l'assainissement en Ouganda : une transformation menee par le gouvernement
doc.abstracts: The note points out that over the past four years, the Ugandan government has conducted sector reform of water and sanitation. This reform has brought a lot of promises. It is intimately linked to plans to reduce the poverty of government and is financed largely by funds freed by debt relief. The reform process has involved a comprehensive assessment of the water sector and sanitation including studies on the sub-urban and rural areas and preparation of action plan and investment. The key strategies that emerge from these evaluations include greater decentralization of service delivery, increased sector participation private, and the need for a sectoral program. Many independent observers believe that this reform process was successful and the most dynamic in sub-Saharan Africa and which we can draw useful lessons for other countries. Yet it is still premature to say what the actual effectiveness of reforms are and say that ideas developed lead to tangible improvements in services and water sanitation to the poor.
